is editorial is entitled, quite simply: Population; 90.000*000 l
Japan continues to face the problem of over-population. The balance between
Japan's territory and resources on the one hand; and the number of people, on
the other, is broken. The importance of the problem is highlighted by the
latest report that Japan's population has^p^P^the 90 million mark. In
August, 1954, the Population Problems Research Council, realizing the need for
quantitative adjustment of the population made a recommendation to the govern¬
ment for a greater information program regarding planned parenthood. This is
not a measure that can solve the population at once; but if left alone, as
it now stands, the balance between population and resources will aggravate.
Two of the undesirable results of over-population are apparent in
unemployment and poverty. It is also causing undue concentration of people
in the big cities. Although there was an unprecedented " bumper harvest"
last year, 10 thousand more people still flocked to Tokyo, There are not
enough jobs to go around, which surely everyone realizes. The gap between
wealth and poverty is increasing. Although Japan suffers from a ljfack
of resources in comparison with population, greater efforts are needed to
develop the available land resources. The population problem, however, is
at the root of the majority of problems faced by Japan,
